reviews.review_title: Did a 5th grader write this screenpaly??
reviews.content: Nope, the 5th grader's screenplay would be better!"The Last Thing Anyone Wanted" should've been the title of this film. What was seasoned writer and director Dee Rees on when she wrote and directed this, and did no one else proofread this convoluted plot ridden excuse for a screenplay?Ugggh, 2 hours of my life I'll never get back! Watch the trailer and you've seen the entire movie - and the trailer makes more sense than the movie if that tells you anything. What a waste of talented actors. A shame this will be a thorn on their resume, I hope they got paid well. NOTHING in this film made any sense. The only thing I got out of this film was to take up smoking; Hathaway was successful in advertising cigarette smoking.The only reason I'm not giving this film a 1/10 is +1 for the actors and +1 for the producers not posting fake/paid reviews - yet. Thus it's a 3/10 from me

reviews.review_title: Seems to think it is a masterpiece when in reality it is quite the opposite
reviews.content: 'The Last Thing He Wanted' begins with a long narration from Anne Hathaway's character. We have no context for what she is saying, and what she is saying is so incredibly dull that it is nearly impossible to focus on what she is saying for the lengthy duration she rambles on for. This sets the tone for a truly shocking film. I can't remember the last time I saw a film so pretentious and full of itself, while concurrently being of such a low standard.Where do I begin with the faults this movie contains? The story is all over the place for starts. It darts around like a headless chook running in circles and never settles down for a moment. The movie asks you to follow every little detail hidden in the dialogue, but the dialogue is so bland and uninteresting that is an immensely tough task to do so. If you haven't completely lost interest in this film 15 minutes in then you have the patience of a saint.I looked up the book this is based on. From what I can tell people were not overly fond of this book. Which begs the question why it got a film when so many incredible books out there have failed to do so. Who read this rambling mess of a story and thought it would make for a great film? Also how did they get a cast as good as they did with a script this bad? I know Anne Hathaway and Ben Affleck's careers have fallen off a cliff, but surely not to this extent? I really did not enjoy this film and even though it's free to watch on Netflix I would suggest it is not worth your time or effort.

reviews.review_title: Good Cast in an Otherwise Confused and Disjointed Movie
reviews.content: Dee Rees, the director of the much acclaimed "Mudbound", offers up her second Netflix collaboration - "The Last Thing He Wanted", a crime thriller based on Joan Didion's novel of the same name. The cast includes such stars as Anna Hathaway, Willem Dafoe & Ben Affleck, also Rosie Perez and Toby Jones. What could possibly go wrong? Apparently a whole lot."The Last Thing He Wanted" is, in a certain way, an annoying experience. Its main strength are the acting performances, the highlights include a content and contained lead performance by Anna Hathaway and a well fitted supporting role for Willem Dafoe. Rosie Perez and Ben Affleck were good as well, but, frankly, they weren't given enough to do to really stand out. It's a mildly frustrating watch because the star-studded power seems wasted on an otherwise weak and confused movie. Or rather the story and screenplay. I can only suppose it's an unsuccessful adaptation of the aforementioned novel. Visually, "The Last Thing He Wanted" is shot very well (and uses a peculiar aspect ratio, but with no complaints), looks and sounds like an above average Hollywood-type thriller. But all of that only matters so much on the background of the script which feels like a lot of things and almost none of them are good - it's disjointed, unfocused, doesn't stick together, doesn't carry the weight it should (I'd take a guess though that the filmmakers think otherwise) and just disappoints altogether. While watching I felt like each scene is somehow to be taken on its own terms, every time the previous one didn't feel important much anymore. What I'm trying to say is that a rather simple story telling has gotten all tangled up here and it's a huge black shadow hovering over "The Last Thing He Wanted".Despite the quite enormous flaw/s, "The Last Thing He Wanted" possesses one or two redeeming qualities. I'll go ahead and assume, probably correctly, that this movie is going to be a bore to a lot of people, but if the viewer commits, it's possible to squeeze out an eyebrow-raising evening 5/10, which is the most I can give it with a clear conscience.

reviews.review_title: No idea what it was about
reviews.content: I just have no idea what the story is about. I don't even understand what the leading characters are doing, or indeed who they really are! The events are confusing, and the characters are poorly developed.

I always check the rates on IMDB before watching a movie in streaming. However this time I followed my wife's decision because she said it was "my kind of movie": political drama/thriller. Big mistake. Terrible script, robotic performances from Hathaway and Afleck. Willem Dafoe was a wasted talent on this one.
Do not bother.

These days I get more and more the impression that the producers don't read scripts anymore - who the hell gave this script a green light? And why!? The story is not very interesting and the execution just adds up to an impression of a redundant and boring movie. Also what's up with those fine actors!? How William Defoe could get involved in this movie!? If he didn't read the script he should fire his agent. Anyway, to be more precise, i renamed the title of the movie to The Last Thing I Wanted, and put it on my personal blacklist that's called "never watch or touch it again". But for certain from a certain perspective it is an achievement to make such a bad movie with that kind of skilled cast... Verdict: one of those fast produced movies that are made these days to fill the airtime of some paychannel. My guess: The Last Thing He Wanted will be faster forgotten than produced.
Just could not make any sense of it. One of the worst films that I've ever seen.

I just created an account specifically for this review. That's how bad, pointless, and confusing this movie was. I felt something in my soul that said I had to let the world know.Plot: Bad/Pointless
Continuity: None
Doesn't tie everything in at any point
Feeling: Am I dumb, did I miss something, or is this movie actually this bad?This film has prompted several questions
Who OK'd this film to be released?
Will I ever forgive myself for wasting 2 hours of my life?While the answer to the first question is obviously "an idiot", the answer to the second question is actually "yes!".There's a silver lining. In wasting my time watching this film, I managed to come across film reviews and ratings of this movie afterwards. I got so much joy and laughter (which I did not receive from watching the movie) out of reading how bad the movie was that I actually am happy I watched it. For every second of misery I endured watching the movie, there was a moment of happiness reading a review of an equally disgusted viewer. The ONLY reason to watch the movie is to laugh at the reviews after!

reviews.review_title: Last Film You Want To See
reviews.content: What a mess! Waste of time, no continuity, script-wise, jumped all over the place. I said WTF is going on with this film? Skip it, IMO.

reviews.review_title: Netflix cannot stop delivering failure after failure
reviews.content:
The cast was promising. The first 5 minutes of tension as well. Then...what the hell? What was this movie all about? I love Anne Hateway but this was a bad decision from her to accept this role. Maybe she didn't read the script before she has signed the contract or the money was too big to say no, who knows. I wonder why almost all movies made in the last couple of years are crap boring low quality material? If i go back and see a list of films in any year of the 80's i can count more excelent movies in a single year then in the last 15 years together. Hollywood writers are more stupid now or they want us to be this low?
Netflix. Your name is equal now to very low rated boring movies.

reviews.review_title: ....was a bad review but he got one
reviews.content: I really wanted to like this movie because the trailer was great and it set the bar high. About a third of the way in I said to my wife, "what the hell is going on?" She didn't know either. Another third into the movie and I repeated the question, which went unanswered because my wife was asleep. Bored by the meandering plot lines that never seem to unite. So, I wasted a few hours of my life watching this but the good news is my wife got an hour or more of decent shut eye.
Just don't do it. Don't convince yourself to watch it because you think "it can't be that bad...."IT REALLY IS

Im usually not a look at my phone while watching a movie kind of person but from the beginning of there movie I found myself looking at my phone. Buy the time out was over I thought that maybe I missed a few key parts because I had no idea what the movie was all about. Came to see what others thought and I see that I didn't miss anything because others were just as confused as I was. This movie feels like they forgot to shoot some scenes that told more of the story. Maybe there's more answers in the book This was based off of.

Now we both know the same amount of information about this movie and I watched it.
Saying it's hard to follow is like explaining duck nuts. I can picture them in my mind but it isn't until I see them in real life that I don't comprehend.

I think some of the poorly rated reviews are a little unfair, but the ending answers a lot of questions about the plot, so stick with it.However, the main question that I had - not satisfactorily answered - is why she went on this journey at all?

I'm big fans of everyone in this movie. But the story was very hard to follow. Both Hathaway and Affleck seem totally off. Hathaway's emotion seems over the top because there's little understandable narrative context. And Affleck seems flat. Things happens, people come and go. The twists and turns strain credulity.Perhaps this worked better as a novel, but even a somewhat strong surprise ending can't salvage this movie.

reviews.review_title: The cast couldn't carry this mess
reviews.content: My god was this horrible. The plot never materialized and, while the cast of all stars was great to see, it lack direction. Something I never thought I would see with the talent and director.Most movies have some underlying moral or idea that they are trying to get across but even that was missing (which is something I rather like but in this instance I thought that maybe it would be what made the whole thing come together.)Bottom line, just don't waste your time. If you do you only have yourself to blame... You've been warned

Let's just say You'd think you'd left the room and missed 30mns of the movie after watching it.. A lot of missing piece and lack of clarity/ explanation.. ultimately you're going to ask yourself wtf did I just watch? Unless you know the story/ read the book already, dont bother watching this!!

reviews.review_title: A Film That Hasn't Found Its Audience
reviews.content: Just tonight I watched "The Last Thing He Wanted" with my family -- two younger siblings (16 and 18) and my mom (60). All four of us loved it. We were all talking happily about it after it was done. I had heard vaguely that it was getting bad reviews, but I hadn't actually read any. Now I'm on IMDb and I'm seeing all these one star reviews. I decided to make an account just to give my own opinion.This movie is hard to follow. That's something everyone here is mentioning. But it seems to me like it wasn't THAT hard to follow. It's only about as convoluted as "The Big Sleep" or "Funeral in Berlin," which don't have rock bottom ratings.That makes me think that this film just hasn't found its audience. I think a lot of people came here looking for action scenes, and got bored with this mainly dialogue driven movie (which was adapted from a novel). I found the movie very tense and thrilling throughout, so that the action scenes came as exciting escalations of the ever-present tension. But if the dialogue is not hooking you, you probably won't be feeling the tension much in the first place.And the dialogue is a big thing. I have no doubt I wouldn't have been able to make sense of the movies without having the subtitles on. The characters talk fast and reference a lot of names (of places, people, and organizations). It expects you to keep up with this rapid fire pace. To be fair, this is just one of the pitfalls of adapting a novel. There are so many words, and if the actors spoke more slowly they'd never be able to fit the whole story in one movie.I think the pacing was truly admirable. Most novel adaptations either have dumb time-skips where you miss important information, or have summary-style scenes where all the interesting dialogue is cut out to leave the plot-relevant information, or have scenes that plod on much longer than they should. "The Last Thing He Wanted" goes at a clip, really rushing from thing to thing. But each point is actually made very well in each scene, and the rush of it becomes pretty exciting. You have no time to stop and think while your life is at risk, and you have no idea who to trust. This ends up demanding a lot of focus from the viewer. I think my family enjoyed it so much because we saw it as kind of a game. We pointed things out to each other and tried to make connections between things.I can understand reviewers who were unpleasantly surprised to find that there isn't much action here, and that the fast-paced dialogue requires a lot of concentration. That isn't everyone's cup of tea. But I also get the sneaking suspicion that people are just frustrated that this movie doesn't spell everything out about the historical background. It frustrates me because the historical background is one of the most urgent things about the movie.Some movies will start with the ABCs because they know their audience doesn't know much about the subject matter. For instance, movies like "Hotel Rwanda" are like an introduction to their subject matter. It doesn't assume that you know very much about the Rwandan genocide. It wants to tell you about it.But if you're always starting from basics, you never get anywhere. Sometimes there are important things to say AFTER you've learned all the basics. That's the kind of movie "The Last Thing He Wanted" is. It expects you to have some familiarity with the political background.And believe me, you should WANT to know more about the political background. Because this stuff is the background of our own lives today. This movie is basically about how America behaves as a superpower -- how it acts at home and how it treats other countries around the world. The way it acts today is not much different. If you try to learn a bit about the background and then keep that in mind while you watch this movies, YOU WILL LEARN SO MUCH THAT IS SO IMPORTANT! Of course, I can't guarantee that you'll like it. But this information is valuable in its own right.Basically, the backdrop for this movie is the Reagan administration's involvement in Central America and the Caribbean. The Cold War was still on, and a group of left-wing Sandinistas came to power in Nicaragua. Reagan opposed this government and backed anti-Sandinista "Contras". He supplied these Contras with arms and funding, and also spoke out publicly in their favour. The problem is that the Contras, to quote Wikipedia, "engaged in a systematic campaign of terror" -- these were not just freedom-loving citizens who opposed leftism, but brutal armies. At the same time, the US government was getting involved in similar ways in El Salvador, Grenada (a Caribbean island), and many other places across the world.Besides the moral problems associated with backing the Contras, there were also the nefarious ways that the government did it. It was not by any means a straight-forward affair -- the CIA and other government agencies acted in almost total secrecy, and a lot of shady dealing got mixed in with the declared actions the Reagan administration was taking.This is the central dynamic of "The Last Thing He Wanted." The shady backroom stuff can't be disentangled from what the government is officially doing. Anne Hathaway's character, Elena, is a journalist who documents the things that the government wants kept secret. Early on in the movie, Ben Affleck's character debates with another Washington guy about whether or not to "allow" her to keep doing her journalism there. The other guy thinks it will help to make things seem more unstable in Nicaragua, and thus give legitimacy to American operations there. Affleck's character, Treat, thinks it's too risky to have the truth come out.The question hanging over the whole film is, who is out to get who? When Elena (Hathaway) starts to get involved in her father's smuggling operation, she doesn't know who is connected to the Sandinistas, who is connected to the Contras, who is perhaps only trying to make money off of drugs, and who is connected to the US government. For people connected to the US government, we have to wonder, do they know Elena is a journalist and care about that, or is she only relevant because of the smuggling thing?Basically, everyone's motives are completely tied up with the political situation at the time. But, let's be real, the world hasn't changed that much. It's exactly the kind of high-handed treatment of other countries which are, in theory anyway, sovereign, which makes China, Russia, and other countries so recalcitrant about accepting US leadership. If this is how the US treats Nicaragua, why wouldn't they treat China the same way?It's also the same attitude which led to the (second) Iraq war. Now, I need hardly remind you that the Iraq war is a huge reason why people are so jaded about politics today. People were lied to on a massive scale, and bought into a costly and painful war over what turns out to have been nothing important. It has given both Republicans and Democrats a sense of powerlessness and cynicism (one of the things which helped elect Trump). Moreover, American prestige has never recovered, and the international well of goodwill for America has become very shallow.Well, that's my little history lesson (and I don't claim to be an expert on any of this stuff). But it gets to the heart of what matters today. The world still works the way it does in "The Last Thing He Wanted," and unlike a movie, you can't just give it one star and tune it out.

The Last Thing He Wanted (.5 out of 5 stars).The Last Thing He Wanted will be a film that you ever wanted to be made. It is one of the worst films ever which nearly everything about it is bad and terrible. Besides having a good cast with Anne Hathaway, Ben Affleck, and William Dafoe. None of the actors had anything good to work with on the script. The script lacked development and story. It was making it difficult to care about anything of the characters on screen. The plot is boring and all over the place which by the time it reaches its end. You do not even care about what just happened. Even a character's death scene felt cheesy and it was hard to care about what happened. Dee Rees direction is tedious, lack the development, and failed to capture the performances these actors could have delivered.Overall, The Last Thing He Wanted is a horrible film.

This film has just come onto Netflix and has a pretty blockbuster cast So I was interested to watch this film and this is my review for the film. The premise of the film sees a journalist who is fed up at work go on a job for her father which causes her to question if the story is worth the effort.Main Character
Anne Hathaway is one of the best actresses around and she is fantastic in this role, she delivers a very memorable and interesting role here. She has some very quick and snappy lines which mixed with her dramatic moments really provides a pretty real character that you can actually sympathise with and was easily the best part of this film.Supporting Characters
Willem Dafoe plays her father in the film and he does a really good job in the role, his character is clearly very shady and messed up but I liked his relationship with Hathaway and felt it was probably the most interesting part in the film and I wish we could have seen more. Ben Affleck is in this film and he does an okay job with what he is given but his character is really boring in this film. He isn't in the film a huge amount and they don't do enough to make you interested in his character. Rosie Perez is also in this film and I just didn't find her character interesting either, she is just Hathaway's friend in the film and doesn't have a defined character in the film.Story
The story is in my opinion the weakest aspect of the film, it just moves all over the place and feels very jarring. It is very confusing and clearly thinks it is clever then it actually is, when Hatheways character works things out it just doesn't make any sense and it leads to lots of characters poping up that don't provide anything to the story. Plus the ending is absolutley crazy and again makes no sense and just leaves more questions then answers and not in an interesting way like some films can.Script
The script has some pretty quick and clever lines especially from Hathaway but the question is whether that is good scripting or whether it is just her performance. The fact that nobody else has any interesting lines in the film I have to believe that is was just her and the script is poor.Style
The style of the film is really nice to look at, it is shot really well and there are some films that build the tension pretty well. But this films pacing is pretty boring it is very slow but isn't interesting which makes it feel longer then it actually is.Overall
Overall this is a very forgettable film that has some decent things about it but really isn't worth a watch.Rating - 4/10.

Considering the very good cast, I was thoroughly disappointed with this movie. Now, I am by no means dumb but I found the storyline extremely difficult to follow. I know it was basically about the U.S. supplying arms to the rebels in El Salvador and that our leading lady's father is somehow involved in a shady arms deal. Other than that, I have no idea.what was going on. Cryptic conversations within a vague and at times totally incomprehensible plot add up to a whole lot of nothingness. Terrible movie that I definitely would not recommend.

reviews.review_title: CIA involvement in Contra cocaine trafficking
reviews.content: A mystery shouldn't be too easy to follow. I found this film's plot enjoyably convoluted, but I remember the Reagan era scandals upon which this story is based. I think it would help viewers to be familiar with the still controversial Iran-Contra affair, and the CIA's involvement in Contra cocaine trafficking. And I think the many 1 star reviews may be politically motivated, in an effort to turn potential viewers away from an eye opening experience. The Last Thing He Wanted wraps up very real political scandals in a very interesting and memorable story.

I won't go as far as saying it was confusing. It just wasn't good. Slow pace is fine when the story, acting, or conclusion are worth it... and this was certainly not worth it. Super boring. Non-coherent, and uninteresting story, with no reputable conclusion. If you're on the fence.. pass.

I'm usually the guy that understands the movie on the fly and gets asked about it by the other. This movie made me feel stupid. I had to google an explanation of the movie, and still makes no sense to me.

reviews.review_title: Okay, it was hard to follow, but...
reviews.content: This movie was hard to follow, but if you just went with it, it had its rewards. The cast was good, the screenplay was sharp, and it wasn't a waste of time. I never understand those Espionage\CIA\Thrillers anyway.

This movie was a complete mess. Kind of a "woke" thing going on..... I can't even convey how stereo-typically "woke" this movie is without getting flagged. It was that ridiculous. So if you get to a point where you find yourself thinking....."WTF ?" ......Yeah, that's when it's time to turn it off and find something else to do. I nap may be in order at that point. Just a terrible mess of an excuse for a film.

Sad. This could have been a good movie. I kept watching it thinking it would get better. It didn't.
Perhaps, when they realized how boring and illogical this movie was someone decided it needed something else, so they added some extended views of burnt bodies, Rosie's lesbian girl friend and Anne Hathaway without one breast even though it didn't have much to do with the movie.
I assume Ben Affleck wasn't told the story line or anything about his character. That made it easy for him. He just had to say his lines without showing any emotion. That was an interesting contrast to those that overacted.

reviews.review_title: a grim grind turns into a confused thriller
reviews.content: In 1982, journalists Elena McMahon (Anne Hathaway) and Alma Guerrero (Rosie Perez) are traveling with rebels in El Salvatore. They barely escape murderous government soldiers and Elena finds evidence of munitions from America. Two years later, she is pushed off her investigation and assigned to follow the Regan campaign. Her father Dick McMahon (Willem Dafoe) is struggling. Her investigation leads to exports of excess American munitions to Nicaragua and Washington insider Treat Morrison (Ben Affleck).The first half is a grim grind. Hathaway is doing a rough no-makeup character. The film is washed out. The camera is often close up. I'm willing to go with the style and at least, Hathaway is trying to do something different. The overall pacing is rather boring and then there is a change in the middle. It starts with something questionable and it doesn't stop. The bad guys try to set her up with a brick of coke. My question is why they wouldn't simply kill her in that random Central American hotel and plant the coke on her. I don't get her relationship with Treat. I don't get why she's using the fake passport. I don't get a lot of this story. I'm willing to believe that she's not doing the smartest things but these things still need to be set up better. It is bad writing compounded by bad directing.

"Some real things have happened lately." Elena McMahon (Anne Hathaway)As I recall Salvador and Under fire, and countless other forgotten investigative political thrillers, I find The Last Thing He Wanted just as much a mashup of intrigues, both international and romantic, maybe more so. With a plot hovering around Reagan, Sandinistas, conflicting American ambitions, and personal baggage, this story merits going back for its history, but even that doesn't promise your understanding. At any rate, it's plot-heavy with material for several movies.Young but experienced journalist Elena travels to South America to collect an arms contraband payoff for her dicey dad, Dick (Willem Dafoe). You know this is not going to come out well, especially since revolutionaries are notoriously poor debtors, not terribly respectful of women, and this revolution a story she was working on anyway.Adapted from Joan Didion's novel, The Last thing He Wanted is probably too faithful to the book and too heavy with its many plot strands. Yet it briefly entertains as interesting eccentrics glide in and out, and a central player, Treat Morrison (Ben Affleck), doesn't justify his place in the plot until the end, where he really places himself, if not too late.Needless to say, I should see this gnarled espionage thriller again to get just the plot right. Yet, why should I have to?"We were moving fast. We were traveling light. We were younger. I was younger" Elena

reviews.review_title: I actually liked this movie. Also I actually understood what was going on.
reviews.content: Okay, so this movie is BOMBING. Apparently people hate it. But, you know, most people aren't saying they don't like it period, they're saying that they couldn't follow it. I could follow the movie, and I liked it a lot. I want to spend this review trying to give the (spoiler-free) background that will help the story make sense. Hopefully with a bit of background, people will be able to make some sense of it, and might enjoy it as much as I did."The Last Thing He Wanted" has an urgent story to tell about politics, power, and violence. It is packed with a crazy amount of details, which is overwhelming, but they are all true (or fictionalized details that are close to the truth). The author of the original novel, Joan Didion, was a journalist like the main character. You need to approach this as a kind of exposé of how politics worked in the 80's and still works today, not as a piece of escapism.In the 80's, the Reagan administration was heavily involved in Central America and the Caribbean. "The Last Thing He Wanted" is mostly concerned with Nicaragua. At the time, a leftist Sandinista government was in power there. As part of the Cold War, the US was supporting a group of "Contras," armed forces fighting against the Sandinistas. The problem is that the Contras were, as it says on Wikipedia, "engaged in a systematic campaign of terror" against the populace.Reagan was vocal in his support of the Contras. Elena (played by Anne Hathaway) quotes him early in the movie, mentioning that he had said "I too am a Contra." However, the extent of US involvement there was kept mostly under wraps. The CIA and other organizations were involved in all kinds of secretive business, including what would eventually be the "Iran-Contra Scandal," something I don't have space to explain here.The whole plot of "The Last Thing He Wanted" plays out against this backdrop. As the movie begins, Elena is investigating the atrocities committed by US-backed soldiers. She's trying to crack open the case so that the government is held accountable. In a very early scene, Treat (Ben Affleck), who I think is in the CIA, discusses with another Washington type whether they should allow her to keep working or not.Their conversation alerts us to the shadiness of the CIA and other US government agencies in this movie. They want to control the conversation in America so that they can act with impunity in Central America. In other words, the question of American democracy at home and foreign policy abroad are inextricable. Elena wants democracy at home and accountability abroad, and that puts her at odds with Washington.So, in the main plot of the movie, when Elena is back in Central America, we are stuck in the middle of all kinds of conflicts. Are the people she is dealing with Sandinistas, Contras, or unaffiliated? Are they connected to the US government, and if so, do they know she's an investigative journalist? Could they be connected to other foreign governments?The situation depicted in "The Last Thing He Wanted" is so relevant, because it's this exact problem which is at the heart of politics today. Now, voters in America are disenchanted with a government they see as unresponsive and unaccountable. Likewise, the world at large is eschewing American leadership, partly out of distrust. Both of these facts can be traced to just such situations as these.If you want to dig a bit deeper into the present political moment, learn more about the world of "The Last Thing He Wanted"! Even if you never like the movie, it's important to understand. Once you know the historical background, I think you'll find the movie much more rewarding, too.

Anne has her way ... sure that's so original she never heard that before ... not. Of course when it comes to this movie, this may or may not be right. She has to uncover something along with the audience ... she has to figure something out ... and there are people in this that try to cover up what she is trying to figure out. The question is, will we uncover what the truth is, before we are .. faced with it? No pun intended and you'll know what I mean, once you see the movie.There are certain twists and turns that we may not expect - or maybe it was just me. But there are some shocking elements to the whole thing. The acting is more than good and the suspense is high from start to finish. Style wise this knows how to draw you in and it knows how to keep you on the edge. Still there are moments that may be drawn out a bit too much and I would totally understand if some feel that the ending may be a bit too clever for how it was set up.Still this has style and is very well made ... a thriller that is clever, for better or worse.

I watched the first half hour of this narrative wondering what the plot was about. Two brave female journalists risking their lives in Central America? Political collusion with terrorism? Family drama with dad sick with Alzheimer? Weapons trafficking?Hathaway is McMahon, the token female heroine. She is reporter allegedly ready to risk everything for her job, working with lesbian photographer Guerrero (the lesbian part is totally irrelevant, like lots of other things).McMahon's dad is Dafoe, a guy with serious mental issues involved in weapons trafficking, who decides to send her daughter in a risky mission, despite the fact that she is the middle of following the Reagan campaign of 1984.I am not sure what Affleck role is because the plot is difficult to follow, jumping left and right, with boring dialogues and lack of focus.The film is just a collection of pieces cut from half a dozen different plots and glued randomly together.

Every now and then a film comes along and you just have to ask yourself (after watching it) how it possibly got released this way. I heard about this film a couple of months ago and absolutely loved the cast involved, so I was kind of eager to watch it. Released by Netflix and directed by Dee Rees, the same woman behind the very good film Mudbound, The Last Thing He Wanted is one of the worst movies I've seen in years. It's not to say that any of the acting is bad, or the Cinematography, or even the directing for the most part, but here's why this movie will likely confuse even the smartest people on the planet."A veteran D.C. journalist loses the thread of her own narrative when a guilt-propelled errand for her father thrusts her from byline to unwitting subject in the very story she's trying to break. Adapted from Joan Didion's namesake novel." That is the description of the film that's given on the IMDB webpage for this film. I decided to quote that, rather than describe this plot myself because even after reading that description, I hardly got any of that out of this film. The film follows Elena (Anne Hathaway) and once she reconnects with her father Dick (Willem Dafoe), the "true plot" kicks in. It was during these few early moments between these two that had me interested, simply due to them just being great actors, but once the story progressed, I found myself lost in this story every few minutes.Adapted by Dee Rees and Marco Villalobos, The Last Thing He Wanted has a screenplay that needed about a thousand rewrites. It felt like a film that was trying to be extremely intricate and smart while failing to deliver any sort of coherency. The description that's used for this movie all over the internet is only about 20% of what this movie is truly about, but if I tried to explain the rest of it, I would probably do it incorrectly or leave things out. It's just far too jumbled to be any kind of memorable. On top of the script being messy plot-wise, the dialogue was incredibly unengaging. I was staring at the screen, trying to latch onto anything anyone was saying, but it just wasn't working.What's even more frustrating about this movie is the fact that everyone seems to believe it's a great movie, so I feel bad for everyone involved with it. The Cinematography by Bobby Bukowski is pretty solid and the performances by Anne Hathaway, Ben Affleck (whose purpose in the movie had me chuckling), Willem Dafoe, and Rosie Perez were all far better than this movie deserved. That's just about all the praise I can give here. Once this movie tries to explain certain story elements in the final few moments of the movie, I was scratching my head and literally asking "What?" out loud.In the end, I'm sure the performances and look of the movie will be enough for some people to enjoy aspects of this film, but it was a trainwreck of a story for me. I usually try to find the absolute best in movies, no matter how good or bad they are, but for myself, I just will never be able to recommend this movie to anyone. Netflix has been releasing some amazing films lately, so this was a huge surprise to me. Not only Netflix, but I really enjoyed the director's previous work in Mudbound. I just think this film is an example of a movie that had many script issues but was made anyways and had no way of being salvaged. The Last Thing He Wanted is a complete mess of a movie, which is a shame.

reviews.review_title: Does Nobody Know That This Was A Novel By Joan Didion
reviews.content: 'The Last Thing He Wanted' is a novel by Joan Didion. A flawless, faultless, word-perfect piece of genius. It was madness to try and turn it into a movie. They left out the key parts of the story and half the characters! No wonder it made no sense to viewers! What audacity to try and re-write a Joan Didion novel! Ridiculous.Ben Affleck's padded, snap-frozen face was just too ghastly to behold. Anne Hathaway wasn't as annoying as usual but completely wrong for the role. The character of Elena is not panicky and running everywhere like a lumpish schoolgirl, she is ice cold and contained and elegant and always in control - if only on the outside. Everything about it was wrong, wrong, wrong. Just leave Joan Didion's works alone. A movie is always less than the book upon which it is based; sometimes a little less, somethings grotesquely less. This was plainly in the latter category.

reviews.review_title: title is fitting for what transpires onscreen
reviews.content: In the midst of the 1984 U. S. Presidential election, a journalist with a moral compass abruptly shifts her focus from covering the political spectrum to caring for her ailing father, even though their relationship is hardly ideal. Then, through a series of circumstances (hats off to viewers who can make any sense of them) she finds herself at the forefront of a black market arms trade in Central America...and the inconsistencies just continue to pile on from there. Ill-conceived political thriller is incoherent to the umpteenth degree, with lots of cloak-and-dagger elements and a narrative that jumps from one story thread to another without any real transition or exposition making it that much more frustrating. Hathaway does try to make this all credible, but is dropped off a cliff (figuratively and otherwise) by the deficiencies of the script, making you wonder if anyone actually comprehended it when they read it. *½

reviews.review_title: Learn some history before watching this
reviews.content: I've never written a review before and wanted to up the rating on this one as I read the other reviews. I totally understand why people find this movie incomprehensible, I think the producers/director assumed people would know about the Iran/Contra days of the 80s, when US Government sold weapons to Iran to fund large scale killings and related militia activities in Central America. This became a sprawling and almost incomprehensible web of crap that consumed America in the 80s. Read about the rape/murder of the Maryknoll nuns, CIA cocaine smuggling to LA, Freeway Ricky Ross (no, not the rapper, but the guy the rapper took the name from and got sued by), the Kerry Commission (yes, Senator / Prez / Married Well John Kerry), Ollie North, Charles Schultz (now of Theranos fame!), and a whole bunch more crazy stuff. Much the current poverty and migration from Central America today is partially rooted in this story, and the many crazy and horrible stories that came before in this region. So, apparently this movie assumes you'll know the story / follow the plot, and if you do it's not a bad flick.

It was based on a book. I like movies that do not spell everything out for you. I could easily untangle it and other films have been more disjointed.
Acting was good. Some nice scenery and different settings made it interesting as well. Two good actors in the leads.
I could not understand the overall low score. I have watched far worse movies that have been awarded a much higher rating.
Would I change the ending? Maybe!

reviews.review_title: I think the problem for most is that politics is horse ****
reviews.content: If you get caught in the game of spies where nothing is what it seems, then that not only confuses everyone involved, you might have to consider that life really isn't that complicated. What you're caught up in is a bunch of dogs given guns and cover that think they can get away with anything, that start out believing they're invincible, and very quickly find out they aren't. If they are lucky, they don't die. If they are smart, they get the hell out of the "game." There is no game, there is only idiots.I think the movie is honest and that's why it's so difficult to follow. I don't feel the characters are badly drawn, they are well drawn, honest, and three dimensional, the writer was just honest enough to acknowledge the stupidity of secrecy when it comes to government affairs and the continuous support for conflict by those that should stop it, because they need a reason to exist. They are so afraid to be unemployed and not able to afford their hookers, drugs, and booze, that they get caught in a game of who-dies-for-nothing-first with an occasional innocent bystander getting it also.I think it's a good movie. Spies aren't just all that "Bond... James Bond? You know the spy that everyone knows and was on the cover of Spy-magazine, third issue of March 1966, with the first ever glossy cover? No, I really looked like that, we didn't have Photoshop back then." Yeah, well...

The last thing he wanted is film that has a bunch of nonsense and entire story is so confusingly told that is hard to understand what is actually plot of film or is this film even has one,even the cast which one is impressive wasnt able to make at least a enjoyable film,i also think that film wants to look and sound like its some kind of award nominee contender but in a fact it was just a bunch of convoluted mess,script is also very weakly written and it didnt matched up with talented actors that were saying them,the last thing he wanted is a film that none of us really wanted to see,but here we are it is just another lame made netflix film and waste of cast in a big way

What did I watch? Couldn't catch the story.. I really tried!
Caos movie and the ending...what was that?

It's honestly embarrassing to see Anne Hathaway and Ben Affleck in this movie. It's everywhere. Everything goes Anne's way in this movie. Look how she escaped from that ambush in the beginning. That was hilariously unrealistic. Lots of other things are implausible in the movie.

reviews.review_title: Like some say, you have to know the era it is from, it is still a work of fiction (?) I believe.
reviews.content: I definitely don't think this deserves to be scored low, I would almost give it 8 stars to make up for the negative reviews. Some of the early part of the movie is basically political commentary on the "dirty wars" in Central America, Nicaragua, in the early '80s but if I am able to get through that stumbling block for some, there's still plenty of movie left and this is based on a novel? I will have to read it.I don't think this is disjointed at all. I admit there are letdowns but many movies have such. Those "letdowns" are not that dire. I would grade it a C, it's fascinating, it's fascinating too, if one has ever been to any of these places, Latin America on the proverbial $10 a day.A historic context here as well. I don't agree with the Nick Nolte movie from the 1980s, "Underfire" but I still think it's entertaining. This is like "Underfire II" for me. Based on true events of the gun-running to the Contras.

How did a movie this bad ever get released? Did Netflix seriously pay for this to be produced? It is as if it was intended to be a mini-series of 8 hours and they forced cut it to under 2, so nothing really made any sense anymore? Absolutely incredible that something with so many incredible actors could turn out so bad. I guess I have to start reading these reviews before I just click the ok button in Netflix. Wishing now that I could somehow get back the last 2 hours of my life that I completely wasted on this utterly incomprehensible movie... Hands down, this is the most disappointed I have been after watching a movie in my life.

you need to know Ummerrikkan History and backyard and rabid antikammyunism.
otherwise you are stuck.

reviews.review_title: A good performance by the always excellent Hathaway can't save this
reviews.content: This might be one of the most nonsensical and badly edited movies I've ever seen. There seems to be no rhyme or reason for any scenes as they just feel randomly put together with no connective tissue. Maybe I'm being harsh on the editor. Maybe this is really just bad writing, and the editor couldn't do much to save what my one of the most badly paced movies I've ever seen. It's less than two hours long, but it feels like four.Whatever this case, Anna Hathaway remains extremely watchable and a phenomenal actress. She's deglamourized with little makeup, but her hair still looks amazing. There's really nothing else to recommend this.
Netflix trash going for quantity over quality. Do not bother

reviews.review_title: the truth can be too extreme for people to know
reviews.content: You may have heard some about US policies in Central America in the '80s, but there were parts of it that went unnoticed. "The Last Thing He Wanted", from Joan Didion's novel, is a fictional look at it. I have no doubt that the sorts of events portrayed here happened in real life. It just goes to show that the thirst for power outweighs all morality. Not a masterpiece, but I recommend it.

reviews.review_title: How to use good actors and produce a bad movie
reviews.content: Script is so confusing, an endless successions of twists, one plot in the top of the other . A political situation in Central America in the 80's should be treated more explicitly by now. In the other hand they concentrate the attention of the audience to the personal drama of a news reporter until is transformed in a scapegoat . What was the intention? To cover the political implications in the US politics or the suffering of a reporter. Cheap melodrama

reviews.review_title: Not quite what I expected, better
reviews.content: I didn't read the book, but had not problem following the plot. I thought that the acting was good and understood the characters . The movie could have done a little more to explain some of the transitions, you were kind of guessing what was going on, but my assumptions were right so the development was as clear. I got it though, and it was worth the wait.

reviews.review_title: Worth watching. Watch the 5 minute video on YT called "What Was the Iran-Contra Affair?" before watching this movie
reviews.content: It is always nice to see a star studded cast in a movie. However, while their performances were good, I believe Willem Dafoe, Rosie Perez and Ben Affleck's talents were underused. There simply wasn't enough room in the script for them to shine.I strongly disagree with the current 4.3 rating this film has. While I agree with those reviewers who say the script feels disjointed, and I agree the story could have transitioned more smoothly and had better editing choices, after reading the reviews, it seems to me that most people gave this movie a low rating simply because they had some difficulty understanding the subject matter. I suggest viewers Watch the 5 minute video on YT called "What Was the Iran-Contra Affair?" before watching this movie.I hope you forgive me, but here comes my rant: I am in utter disagreement with USA tv pandering to the lowest common denominator. American tv has been doing this for the last 30 to 40 years, under the excuse that they need to use simple words and simple story lines, so that "everybody" can understand. I instead am an optimist: I believe low quality education doesn't have to equate slow thought capacity. I believe in the plasticity of the brain. When challenging content is presented and becomes the norm, people tend rise to the occasion.I see the low rating of this movie as symptomatic of a public which for generations has rarely been challenged in the context of entertainment; a public who rarely watches (let alone read) the news, knows little about geography and even less about their own history, and has unfortunately become complacent. Yes the script has some problems, some events could have transitioned better, and if that meant a longer movie or a mini series in stead of a movie, so be it. But to give this a low rating, just because the subject matter is "demanding", is preposterous in my opinion.

reviews.review_title: It's not like buying ice cream
reviews.content: Anne Hathaway plays Elena McMahon a fictional reporter for the Atlantic Monthly. She is caught up in reporting on US arms going to Central America, something she discovers her ailing father (Willem Dafoe) is involved. She fills in for him to get a story and for the million, which she discovers is actually cocaine.In the film, the character lost a breast to cancer so they felt a need to show Anne minus a breast, something they could have left out. The ending was odd and without the typical closure, although we know what happened and the criminals got their own TV show on Fox News.Guide: F-word. Nudity.

It's more likely a 7-8 and the 3-4 is like an internet mob protest vote.Glad I watched it without checking reviews first.Most of the complaints seem to be around the story and that it was too difficult to follow, was boring or annoying character actions and I'll address these below.First and foremost, if you've never heard about Contras before or watched a movie on it, straight up certain things are probably going to be more confusing for you. This includes not only the plot and settings but also why the 'bad guys' are doing bad things.While there are some action scenes this is more of a slower thriller (which after seeing the trailer (after watching the movie), I can see why some would seem to be misled especially those with short attention spans).As for the main character's actions, it can be boiled down to her love for her father (the title is "The Last Thing He Wanted" after all) intertwined with her investigative journalistic drive to uncover the truth further mixed in with who on earth should she trust.Finally, there is no feel good Disney happy ending for everyone here.PS: Acting was great and there was nothing wrong with the cinematography.

reviews.review_title: The Last Thing He Wanted Review
reviews.content: This joke has been made a thousand times but The Last Thing He Wanted perfectly resembles how I feel about this movie. It was the last thing I wanted to see. There is so much that is wrong with this film. Whenever I watch a movie for the first time, I pay full attention to it so that I don't miss any details. After watching this, I thought, "What?". I don't understand what this movie was about or what happened. Its plot is so convoluted and confusing that I honestly can't tell you what happened. The film has little to no structure to it. Scenes just happen and then they go on to another unrelated scene. Since I couldn't understand what was happening, I was incredibly bored. This is one of the most boring films I have ever seen. None of the characters are interesting or developed in the slightest. I like Ben Affleck, Anne Hathaway, and Willem Dafoe but I hated their characters. They are all unlikeable and don't have any motivation for what they do. Anne Hathway's character doesn't like her father at all and yet she decides to take over his job? It made no sense. Their performances weren't that great either. Willem Dafoe was fine and his performance was the only aspect I found above average but Affleck and Hathaway were pretty bad. Hathaway sounded like a robot the entire film and Affleck who has top billing was only in the film for 15 minutes. He contributed almost nothing to the film. The other actors did a pretty poor job and were very forgettable. I honestly forgot that Toby Jones was in the film until I started writing this. The script they were given was particularly awful. The dialogue was poorly written and shallow which hampered everyone's performance. The cinematography was fine. It wasn't special but it wasn't bad. The editing was particularly annoying though. It would cut randomly during scenes which threw off the focus of it. At other points, the editing would cut so rapidly and quickly that it was hard to tell what was going on. Overall, The Last Thing He Wanted is a convoluted, confusing, and boring film with a poor script, bad characters, and obnoxious editing.

It's difficult to believe two things here: that so few people remember the Contra War in Central America during the Reagan administration; and that so many people can be influenced to lag a film about it because it indicts the Reagan-Bush party line of war profiteering and human oppression, the actions that have up till the present created an enormous and deadly narcostate from Tegucigalpa to Ciudad Juarez.We live in a time when millions support a presidency which builds a wall at our southern borders to "protect" us from people fleeing Central American countries destroyed by the narcotics, police and military predation created by the Contra War. Persons who would demean the retelling of the horrors of 1980s El Salvador and Nicaragua, or would, for money, post messages condemning a film that reminds us of this outrage, should have to answer for their actions, either by researching and understanding history, or by ending up on its wrong side, as did too many of the people of Central America, then and now.
Was this one of many potential side stories of the Iran/Contra scandal? It was an engaging story until the bitter end. But, way too much was left to the imagination.

Okay, I get it, most of you don't like this movie. That's fine for sure. But 'movielovers' who gave only one star to this flick and cry their eyes out because they can't understand the storyline, should find another hobby. The story is intriguing, the acting is great, as is the cinematography. Why so much hate?
The only type of person who could enjoy this movie would be a young dumb liberal wannabe journalist....but even they would find the story a garbled mess.

Not much to say here within this film. Quite a standard and generic Netflix production film. At first the story was decent and there are some moments of intrigued but in general the story isn't too interesting, and it's been done many times before. The cast isn't the problem, as Anne Hathaway is very solid as this is essentially a one-woman lead film.If deciding to watch this film for being fans of any of the cast members, do not expect much as after all this is a Netflix film released in February.

The movie was different and thought provoking...as to what really might go on behind the scenes with covert government operations. I can see where others may not like this movie...but I for one really enjoyed it.

reviews.review_title: Not sure why such low reviews
reviews.content: First off this is not a brilliant spy story. And I kinda hate the ending. That being said I think the real low reviews are overly harsh. The movie has some pretty good twists. A reporter tries to help out her father on one last score even though it is shady as all hell but there is a story in it for her but she pretty quickly lets in over her head. The acting is pretty good and the story itself has some interesting twists. Again this is not a work of art and will not gain anyone any awards. But it is also not horrible.
Very boring movie. Find something else worth watching.

IMDB should include a minus in their ratings, cause there are some movies which especially needs this kind of treatment.
The last thing He wanted should be title as The Last Thing You Don't Want to See. A movie with no rhyme, a clueless, bad making and horrible use of the cast. Ben Affleck is not in the lead of main character, he has less time on the screen than someone with a special appearance, so don't fall for it.
Anne Hathaway was confused through out the movie and so were the audience, we both share the same feeling like What On Earth is Going On.
It certainly make the list of horrible movies ever made.

reviews.review_title: The devil Wears Prada guerrilla edition
reviews.content: Devil wears Prada guerrilha edition: Don't waste your time watching it! I think they just made the film very confusing so the audience can't see the garbage the story is

So sick of the hate
This is a very decent movie. A bit confusing but it adds to the mystery and suspense. Kind of a whodunnit IMO. The acting of course is believable. The scenery is gorgeous and the sound perfect. Honestly, this movies a solid 7 I've added 2 points to offset the pure ridiculous of others.
Very disappointing. Foggy plot. Twists and turns that make no sense.

Having read the bad reviews I nearly stopped this at the 20minute mark. I kept watching and really enjoyed it, with all the twists and turns. I get what some are saying about how it jumps but I think that is to reflect Elena'a hectic life before she finds her father is ill and she then takes over his one last job. Not sure if I liked it more because of the bad reviews and I had low expectations. I did find myself replaying in my mind the story, which for me is always a good sign.

The story makes no sense as it goes on. Never known a film like it.
Starts off like you know what's happening, then takes turn where you are asking yourself what just happened and what did I miss. Very confusing!

reviews.review_title: Written and Directed by Women For Women.
reviews.content: Too bad we are not hiring creatives based on the abilities anymore. How do you put this together and say, 'yeah, good job'! Well you hire a group of people that all think alike.I love Anne Hathaway and Willem Defoe and can only think they did this as a favor.

reviews.review_title: 6 stars only for the excellent acting.
reviews.content:
Anne Hathaway showed her best in this movie and her role alone saves this movie from disaster. Bad editing, script but good characters made so by all the great interpreters of this movie. Too bad, it could have been a little masterpiece all gone to waste by a confusing story-line and editing.
However, the whole situation of the Iran-Contra affair is real and future generations should know how much the American public had been deceived by an incompetent president like Reagan who was very much loved, but just a puppet in the hands of wolves. Having presented this scandal with true drama makes this a noteworthy movie in spite of its mishaps.
1 is an exageration - what a pretentious dreadfully written and acted piece of xxxx..I love movies and have watched thousands, good and bad, but this sets a new low in cinema
Needlessly complicated and ultimately unbelievable story with some good moments of acting by Anne Hathaway.
I was confused through out the movie, wondering what is the purpose of this and is there an end to it. If there is a second choice, choose that, really not worth watching.
The film talks about a very important political issue ... the way events are reported and listed by a chef and excellent ... The acting is very good, but the end could have been better than that.
Can I get that time back? Not one thing made any sense.

By the title I thought it was a heavy drama, but it is a political dramatic film, always great performance by Anne Hathaway, and especially excellent work by Joan Didion, captivating, tangled, close to perfection, I thought it was real facts, very good, great outcome, sad...

I had not heard of this movie but was attracted to see it because of its stars.... The beginning of the film seemed promising but as it went on the story was confusing and disconnected but hoped that the story's ending would make ends meet - but did not ...!
Serves me right for not first checking IMDB before watching this really verrrrry bad film !

reviews.review_title: Terrible movie. Disjointed, random scenes, no sense
reviews.content: Worst movie ever, waste of time , impossible to follow, random scenes, who edited this? Zero continuity.

This film is a moody throwback to 70s and 80s political thrillers and it's set in the Nicaraguan controversies and such, mostly stuff of the Reagan era. At the same time, it's a character-driven picture and a tropical romance set in the world of international intrigue. So, yeah, there are a lot of moving parts, and Dee Rees takes the Michael Mann route of making the audience pay close attention to how the story unfolds without making it easy in the storytelling department. Anyhow, I managed to follow the plot and if you feel it's convoluted or silly you should consult Didion novel. Also it's an unofficial remake of Antonioni's PASSENGER with Anne Hathaway taking over the Jack Nicholson part. For me, it made sense for what it is - a backbone for a sweaty and highly stylized excercise in arty thrillers like they used to make them in the seventies.Anne Hathaway is mesmerising in the leading role. Ben Affleck is good as the White House sleazebag involved with her. Toby Jones is a delight as an old semi-retired pimp who still knows how to create an intrigue. And above all else Bobby Bukowski does an impressive job as the director of photography. This film should be seen for his contribution alone.Admittedly, it's an acquired taste but not the kind of film that should be hated with such passion. Check it out on Netflix and later on you can make a nice conversation by comparing it to Mark Neveldine's Panama which basically deals with same stuff but in a completely different production milieu and ambitions.

Watched ten minutes, counldn't make head nor tail of it, so ditched it. Came on IMBD to read the reviews to see if I was maybe missing something and should perservere, but it seems most other people were as baffled as me.

Most public won't get it - Briliant camera, cut, plot that will intrigue you only if your attention span and life experience is as sharp and adrenaline filled as the characters' the film portrays... This film is beyond general simple straight plot lines, it leaves a holistic impression which either matches or mismatches with you... Ad the cast, I would suggest, that this is one of the best Affleck's roles (not being his fan generally, his fit and performance in this movie is perfect).
It is not an easy listening. Try again...

reviews.review_title: Not perfect but I believe the movie definitely deserves more stars than majority of the current ratings.
reviews.content: First off Hathaway was amazing as always! Her father played by Willem Dafoe was also amazing. Now similar to my review I wish the time was àvailable to dig deeper into everything that was going on. They either should have gone full on Irishman or done a Mini-series. Well keep an open mind to some of the unnecessary Hollywood add on's lay back and enjoy the story.

reviews.review_title: The last thing I wanted was another Netflix 'B' grader
reviews.content: I like these types of gritty investigative / corruption / reality vs. idealism tales ... but this is ordinary. Whats irks me is the number of quality name actors who jump on board Netflix flicks ... they have woken up to the idea of the gravy train and are fully on board ... with no regard for the quality of the production and how it will affect their reputations and credibility. Affleck does his pretend adult role, though his bloated face is obvious ... did anyone mention alcoholism? Hathaway does a splendid makeup-less job of being a serious adult ... quite a good effort but did she have to show her breasts in the one hapless love scene with the pretend adult? What was she thinking? ... probably thinking about the big fat pay cheque? Dee Rees the director is apparently quite awarded so she's no amateur when it comes to making a movie ... so did she sit down with the script writer and editor and say "This isn't working"? From the way unrelated scenes were thrown together, culminating in the ending where the heroine falls quite literally into a hole, this movie falls into a hole ... what were they thinking?

reviews.review_title: Fading all star cast r are getting to that age....."Woman on the move", stumbles..
reviews.content: The story is about a "real firecracker" of a gal reporter during the Regan Iran-Contra years. With her hard driving (grating?) personality it becomes clear early on that she truly is a "woman on the MOVE'. PROBLEM ! This chick is played by Ann of Hathaway, and her acting ability seems to be fading faster than her looks. She's reportedly 37, but suddenly appears much older. The rest of the fading star studded cast include other Hollywood staples including , but not limited to, Ben Affleck, Rosie "versatile hispanic alpha female" Perez, and they even make William Dafoe look talentless. Don't know why the director had all the players deliver their lines so fast , like they were in a Lifetime channel production, or a porno, but it makes them look bad.Ms Hathaway early on has a fight with her editor about being pulled off a story. She flits around the office like a valley girl on crack, and , back away from the sunlamp Ann , it's bad for you. I remember hearing Hathaway interviewed by Terri Gross a couple of years back, and when she described playing a "plain Jane" character started fishing for compliments wildly from Gross; now I see why. In this piece when she faces off with New York actors playing central American gangstas it becomes laughable. Hathaway putting on a hard chick act is like casting Michelle Williams (that billboard of vunerability) as a Cholla...She pulls a gun on a driver and car jacks him, major cred problems..Rosie Perez is of Puerto Rican dissent, but seems to be Hollywood's resident Latina, as I saw her and fellow countryman John Leguizamo cast as Mexicans in LA in some other nebulosity. Her accent and voice are going from cute and perky to annoying and grating as she ages very quickly. Ever wonder what she REALLY sounds like?The only way to watch this movie and enjoy it is as a spoof, and thats made easy by the 80s get ups they have put everybody in. Dafoe is doing his imitation of Pacino, Perez of Rita Moreno, and Hathaway of her younger and more entertaining self. I watched as long as I could until , like a couple of big macs a fries, this junk food for the brain became too much. I shouldn't have super sized the fries...

Favorite scene withElena (Anne Hathaway) -
Her first "job" for her dad - getting on the plane, going to the location, delivering the goods, waiting for payment, and demanding it when she doesn't get it.Alma (Rosie Perez) -
Trying to find out which hospital Elena's dad was taken to.

Of course films now require some kind of salute to the LGBQ etc. crowd even if it has nothing to do with the story, so please enter Rosie Perez. Cigarettes have made huge comeback as a prop in movies and Ann Hathaway takes full advantage. Enough! This movie stunk but I don't know how much since I turned it off a third of the way through.

I really enjoyed this film. Sure it was mostly a slow paced movie that requires that the viewer listen closely and pay attention, but that doesn't make it a bad movie. I don't get what the bad reviews were about; I thoroughly enjoyed this. Missed opportunity, could have been a great movie. Some scripting, editing and pacing issues make the story harder to follow that it should have been. Its an intriguing story with a great cast. This movie is a good watch but it could have been a blockbuster. I am disappointed that its not.

I told my wife it wasn't out fault - the movie just sucked, but she said she felt stupid not being able to follow it. Thank you IMDB reviewers for providing her with some comfort. This and 'birdbox' (or whatever that tripe was called) are neck-in-neck for the most horrible Netflix movies with decent actors. I have a feeling the next bit of competition is waiting in the wings. Might not be so easily suckered then.

The only reason I gave it 2 stars is because I like Anne Hathaway. Random people, random places, NO idea how and if anything is connected . Characters are not connected, plot is not connected to the characters, nothing makes sense
whoever directed and produced this movie must have been on heavy drugsterrible waste of talent
Quality acting. Could have been great. Terrible plot that literally went in circles. It was like 10 dead end stories crammed into one movie.

reviews.review_title: a frustrating story shown in a silly way
reviews.content:
Ann Hathaway's character implicates herself in some major criminal activity opposite to her beliefs, for no good reason other than the family connection, and then just gets completely lost in the events, running around like a headless chicken, not knowing anything anymore, with everyone else wanting to get rid of her. The situation is shown pretty much solely from her point of view, leaving the viewer tired and bored of being clueless of what is happening and of what may happen further on.
While the events are vaguely realistic, it is completely pointless to show them this way.I'm giving this movie an extra star for portraying some of the interesting hostorical events, but that's it.

Anne Hathaway really played this one well. it was chaotic and Intentionally hard to follow, But I have to imagine That is what being a reporter in the middle of the Iran Contra scandal would have been like, it makes sense that you would potentially trust the wrong people, or feel safe in your first world privilege. people seem to be upset because the story was hard to follow, and they disagree with the actions the character took. but that is what made it feel real to me. sometimes you can't see your enemy even though they are staring you in the face. people want their movies like they want their lives, prepackaged and easily palatable. This movie made some strong choices on the plot that may not have made the arc clear, but drove home the reality that life is Fd up and people aren't what they seem. Now I want to read the books.

reviews.review_title: Ambitious and Disjointed but ultimately successful
reviews.content:
There are only 10 (now 11) user reviews and all of them to this point have been in the negative and one hopes that this will turn the tide for the beleaguered film from Dee Rees.
A ragged patchwork quilt of issues, news, raw footage of countries, coasts, wars, bodies, boxes and bags colours flapping half heartedly in the wind.
Strong performances from all most notably an intense but constrained one from Hathaway who up until this film has never impressed me. I like her in this gritty, angry, taut and gaunt un-Hollywood journalista role. Her backstory is breast cancer survivor, disaffected mother, angry daughter, ex-wife and integrity driven outsider clothed in leftovers from the left behind bin in a laundromat in Miami.
Rosie Perez is her friend and trusted cohort who turns in an understated and competent performance.
This film was not pretty to watch. It was messy, disjointed, illogical like life itself so if that is what you want go watch La La Land.

reviews.review_title: The screenplay doesn't have any sense

in and out of South America to get a big story as well

The Last Thing He Wanted: It's 1984, Anne Hathaway is a reporter, an old hand on the Central America beat, a thorn in the side of the State Department. But her grifter father Willem Dafoe is ill, he's gotten involved in CIA plans to send arms to the Contras. Inexplicably she agrees to take his part in the exchange. Ben Affleck is a duplicitous US intelligence operative with Toby Jones as a burned out CIA asset. It's all a bit too convoluted with the motivations of several of the characters difficult to comprehend. 5.5/10. On Netflix.

reviews.review_title: Good try, but too disjointed for many I'm sure.

The overall story is really interesting and the actors hold it together enough to be worth a watch. 5/10

reviews.review_title: Anne Hathaway kicks ass in This film
reviews.content: Dee Rees' "The Last Thing He Wanted" is incomprehensible to an almost impressive degree-usually when a movie's narrative gets so out of control, it over-corrects itself at some point before the end. But not here. This international anti-thriller, which freely mixes hardworking journalism and weapons smuggling, continues to blaze its own path of gibberish up through a disastrous finale. It's the kind of movie that establishes one major detail or location, and then veers toward the next big one, and never lets us settle in. The first 15 minutes or so, for example, establish that Anne Hathaway's extremely dedicated journalist Elena McMahon has done some heroic work in Nicaragua; along with her peer Alma (Rosie Perez), they escape the country in a thrilling shot that goes from outside the airport onto the runaway in one swoop. Moments later, Elena is back behind a desk at her job at the Atlantic Post, but her work has been stagnated by her employers, who want her to cover the 1984 election, which infuriates her. So she does that, and Rees establishes the election race with a few large sets of campaign rallies. But that's not the main story. Because at the same time, it becomes apparent that the very story she's been working on about smuggling has a personal connection, as her father Richard (Willem Dafoe) is in the middle of the weapons business. In a rambling bit of conversation that struggles to establish this and also their father-daughter dynamic, Elena takes a job for her father, wearing both her reporter and amateur smuggler caps. Hathaway is nonetheless all-in on this performance, and if the movie were more focused with Elena's intent I suspect her sincere work would be better received. Instead she comes off as a character at the center of a parody about a hard-working, fearless journalist, who has a magic intuition when it comes to making the right bold move, and later can hold her own against menacing weapons dealers like Edi Gathegi's Jones. In reoccurring quieter moments, Hathaway has an emotional core of being a detached mother, and a survivor of breast cancer, but both are distinct character elements that are lost in the fray.

This was truly a great movie in line with movies like memento. Some things appeared unrealistic until the answers come and things make sense, but not in a neatly tied bundle which I felt refreshing. The loose ends gave me an idea of how the main character felt. Nothing was real, nothing was certain, too many things are going on, confusion, chaos, paranoia--it was all there. This was a rare movie that forces you to read in between the lines and get it wrong!, therefore adding to the confusion. I always felt like I was floating on a major event that fell in the water, dissipated and I sank in with it. Just like in real life, the story just became a piece of history that had relevance, got mired in a bundle of patriotic partisan confusion and now means nothing. Avoid the critics, do not miss this movie. Absolutely excellent. I never liked Anne Hathaway--I have changed my mind.

Another bad film from Netflix, as you can see from the low ratings, so we can keep this short. There is plenty wrong with the movie, but it is mostly the casting that really hurts. The characters become completely unbelievable because of this. Add to this a bad built up, lots of confusion in the plot, a lack of visual cues and clues and you get a bad film. I'm a big fan of Anne Hathaway, but this role was not made for her. Forget about this one.

reviews.review_title: Acting is good but storyline is confusing
reviews.content:
Some people have talked about this being part of the Iran Contra and outlined the political shenigans of the Reagan administration Some people have made comments on political misbehavior of the Reagan administration. The reality is that Congress is the bad guy in all of this because they supported a communist brutal government of the Sandinistas who were corrupt and involved heavily in drug trade and killed their own people as well Congressional foreign affairs and intelligence committee was also briefed in these operations This is because Congress did not want to fund the contras as did not want to fund anti Castro regime during the Cuban revolution It always amazes me how people rationalize this is bad but the Nicaraguan Sandinistas govt are good people which is bs We funded the the Afghans during their war with Russia

This is not believable Why would there be a French operative to support the Santinistas This story makes no sense There was a movie with Tom Cruise about the drug dealing and dealings with Iran contra which made more sense than this story The sad thing if we have send the US military to overthrown the Nicaraguan govt which would have been accomplished in one day which we did in one day in Granada and Panama and also bombed Libya this would been the end of the Nicaraguan govt By way the journalist was a typical anti war pro communist liberal Democrat She dying for her cause was sad but also shows that journalist do unfortunately get killed in hostile situations and risking for the story also shows you have to be realistic about dangers involved The reality is that this story if revealed in 1984 presidential campaign would not have much impact When you start talking about CIA operations this is meaningless because Congress is also briefed on theses operations This operation was underway before Congress banned funding of the contras and in reality the Congress was aware of Iran Contra

I really have no idea what happened. I didnt know 20 minutes in, 30 minutes in, 1 hour in, or by the end. My husband was like "maybe we will find out at the end". Well we didnt. I dont know if I'm just dumb and that's why I didnt get it, or if it was that confusing. The reviews here comfort me a little in that other people dont seem to understand what happened either.Theres no plot synopsis online anywhere, so I guess that nobody in the world was able to figure it out and summarise it online. Some of my questions:Who even was Ben Afflecks character and why did he care what Anne Hathaway was doingWhat relevance did her mum dying/her daughter/her breast cancer haveWhat story was she coveringWho were all the people she stayed with and why did she get suspicious of them and keep moving aroundWhy did Ben Affleck wait till the end of the movie to kill her if that's what he wanted to doWho helped her change her name and whyI just feel like I watched a whole load of scenes with a tonne of acting but none of the scenes were explained and I dont have a clue who anyone was.Ahwell at least our baby fell asleep.

reviews.review_title: Last time I do not follow my gut
